<[silence:3400]>
"Stone bridges. Iron tools. Cathedrals that defy time."
<[silence:2400]>
The term medieval engineering refers to the practical problem-solving of the Middle Ages—when builders, blacksmiths, and monks turned raw materials into lasting marvels.<[silence:2400]

Most people picture castles and knights.<[silence:1200]>
But the real breakthroughs were hidden in the details.<[silence:2400]
Take the ribbon vault: a ceiling design that distributed weight like a spiderweb, letting Gothic cathedrals soar higher than ever.<[silence:1200]
Or the trebuchet, a siege engine that hurled 300-pound boulders using nothing but gravity and a counterweight—like a seesaw turned weapon.<[silence:2400]
Monks copied manuscripts, but they also invented the mechanical clock in the 1300s, using gears to track hours instead of sundials.<[silence:1200]
And the waterwheel? It didn’t just grind grain—it powered forges, sawmills, and even early blast furnaces.<[silence:2400]
No computers. No lasers. Just wood, stone, and relentless trial-and-error.<[silence:1200]
The results still stand today.<[silence:2400]

Roman concrete recipes lost and rediscovered.
The first cranes, built from timber and rope.
How a single arch could hold up a city’s weight.
